description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Women for Women's Human Rights-New Ways (WWHR) has applied to Sida for funding of 24 million SEK to carry out their strategy activities of the NGO during the period 2018-2022. The intervention aims at sustainable change and transformation rather than short-cut and transitory solutions to women’s human rights issues. WWHR believes that for sustainable change to occur, a mental shift needs to take place at the societal level, reach a critical mass, and converge with strengthened and improved normative systems at the national and international levels. Sustainable change results from: • Producing and sharing knowledge: Creating enabling spaces to link action-research with knowledge generation and sharing, and disseminating the generated knowledge through publications and other audio-visual, published, and digital means, • Building capacity, raising awareness, and women’s empowerment: Building capacity, raising awareness, and promoting women’s empowerment through education and support programs with women, women’s rights organizations, activists, youth, practitioners, state institutions, and other rights-based organizations, • Advocacy: Taking part in joint and participatory advocacy work at the local, national, regional, and international levels by protecting, enforcing, and improving legal rights, putting the necessary mechanisms into practice, and raising awareness to ensure that women’s human rights are realized. • Networking: Networking and solidarity with all levels of the women’s movement and other rights-based movements through efforts to build capacity, raise awareness, promote women’s empowerment, and advocacy. All these domains feed one another and work in a cycle, rather than as a linear process. The intervention’s total budget is 24 million SEK for 5 years.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Women for Women's Human Rights-New Ways (WWHR) har ansökt om finansiellt stöd om 24 MSEK från Sida för genomförandet av organisationens strategiska aktiviteter under perioden 2018-2022. Insatsen ämnar bidra till hållbara förändringar som stödjer kvinnors mänskliga rättigheter. WWHR anser att hållbara förändringar endast kan ske när en mental förflyttning skett på samhällelig nivå, en kritisk massa deltar, och när dessa sammanfaller med stärkta och förbättrade normativa system på nationell och internationell nivå. Hållbar förändring nås genom: • Kunskapsproduktion och spridning: Skapa utrymmen för att stärka utbytet mellan aktivism och forskning för att generera kunskap och spridning av denna genom publiceringar och andra audio, visuella, tryckta och digitala medel. • Kapacitetsbyggande, medevetandehöjande och kvinnors stärkta egenmakt: Kapacitetsbyggande, medevetandehöjande och stärkandet av kvinnors egenmakt genom utbildning och stöd till kvinnor, kvinnorättsorganisationer, aktivister, ungdomar, professionella utövare, statliga institutioner och andra rättighetsbaserade organisationer. • Påverkansarbete: Deltagande påverkansarbete på lokal, nationell, regional och internationell nivå för att skydda, genomdriva och förbättra juridiska rättigheter, säkerställa att nödvändiga mekanismer används, och öka medvetenheten för att säkerställa att kvinnors mänskliga rättigheter realiseras. • Nätverkande: Nätverka och verka i solidaritet med kvinnorörelsen och andra rättighetsbaserade rörelser genom insatser för att främja kapacitetsbyggande, medvetandehöjande, kvinnors egenmakt och påverkansarbete. Dessa domäner faller in i varandra samt sker i cykler, och är därför inte att förstå som en linjär process. Insatsen totala budget omfattar 24 MSEK för en femårsperiod.

Women for Women’s Human Rights – New Ways (WWHR) is a women’s NGO in Turkey that aims to promote women’s human rights, equality and non-discrimination at national and international levels. Since its foundation in 1993, WWHR has become a well known NGO in its area. More than two decades of work on activism, advocacy and networking, WWHR has worked for making contributions to various legal reforms, increasing women’s awareness and enjoyment of their rights in Turkey, advancing sexual and bodily rights in Muslim societies and also worked on women’s human rights at the UN level. Recipient of the 2007 Gruber Foundation International Women’s Human Rights Prize, WWHR had held special NGO Consultative Status with the Economic and Social Council of the UN since 2005. In June 2017, WWHR embarked on a new strategic planning process to identify how it can continue to fulfill its mission to spread rights awareness from a feminist and women rights perspective at the local, national, regional, and international levels; contribute to women’s equal, influential and unobstructed participation in life and advocate for the protection and strengthening of women’s human rights. Based on the lessons learned from the previous Strategic Plan executed over the past five years (2013-2017) and the current sociopolitical situation in Turkey, WWHR aimed to develop an overall strategic framework and roadmap for its operations in line with the Results Assessment framework. The concrete activities and operations proposed with the current Strategic Plan covers the upcoming five years (2018-2022), and is planned to be regularly reviewed and revised on the basis of Annual Operational Plans. This new strategy is an updated version of the previous strategies and by this strategy, WWHR's mission is set as "to spread awareness of feminist rights at the local, national, regional and international levels; contribute to women’s equal, influential, and unobstructed participation in life; and advocate for the protection and strengthening of women’s human rights." This proposal of WWHR is aligned with the latest developments Turkey that has been through such as increased conservatism, shrinking space, Syrian conflicts/migration, challenges/limitations created by conservative central government and local administrations, Feto and PKK operations, State of Emergency (SoE), increased terror attacks by ISIS and PKK, closure of NGOs by the government through decrees, miltary involvement wwith YPG forces in Syria etc. It would be also important to mention here that WWHR is very much dependent on international funding in particular to Sida due to their feminist stance against government's (unofficial) conservative ideological agenda (gender equity/justice).

description.narrative: WWHR, has continued to perform as expected in 2020 despite the challenges created by Covid. It is assessed from the annual report and from the review meeting that WWHR has managed to realise many of their activities, when necessary adapted the activities to online and cancelled/postponed when needed. THEMATIC AREA 1: RAISING RIGHTS AWARENESS, CAPACITY BUILDING, AND WOMEN’S EMPOWERMENT: Aid in the empowerment and build the capacity of various beneficiary groups and institutions on rights awareness through trainings, awareness-raising programs, and training publications/materials. Under this area of work WWHR continued to coordinate and provide support to its trainers working at municipalities and local women’s organizations and training participants until the outbreak of the pandemic. Many planned activities had to be suspended and WWHR had to revisit and revise its 2020 activity plan. The activities had to be implemented online and they organized virtual meetings with trainers and partners; publicizing the recordings of these meetings. WWHR as a response to the pandemic developed a new training tool—the Online Gender Equality Seminars (GESs)— which is comprised of 7 new seminars on gender equality and rights; and realized a three-day Online Orientation Training. WWHR, very importantly, continued to establish new collaborations with new partners ranging from municipalities to private sector companies and women’s organizations. During the period between January and mid-March, nine Gender Equality Seminars were implemented in the field, through online implementation with cooperation with Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality. Additionally, in the framework of project led by Family Planning Foundation with Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality, WWHR conducted trainings on economic and social rights with the participation of Roma women in Istanbul. In fall 2020, WWHR signed Partnership Protocols with two more municipalities, which increased the number partnerships to 16 municipalities. The activities that required face-to-face contact could not be implemented due to Covid-19 restrictions and official bans. THEMATIC AREA 2: LOCAL, NATIONAL, REGIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL ADVOCACY: Advocacy, policy development, and awareness-raising to develop new legislation, and monitoring and strengthening current legislation that will safeguard women’s human rights and the achievement of gender equality in Turkey and worldwide, by supporting the formation of connections between national and international processes and the establishment of solidarity networks. WWHR and many other women’s rights organisations have been challenged by the rising global and national attacks against gender equality, LGBTI+ rights, and human rights. It is reported by WWHR that the pandemic period has made advocacy efforts even harder to obtain the results and to affect the decision makers both at national and multilateral levels. However, it is assessed that WWHR has made use of all channels of online communication and advocacy methods to mobilize international institutions against these attacks. It is observed by Sida that WWHR’s contribution to these efforts at national level have been highly effective is spite of the pandemic. WWHR has also shown great effort to make the interlinkages between feminist & LGBTI+ organizing and awareness raising in the face of all attacks, carrying all relevant advocacy events such as workshops, and panels online to discuss, strategize, and advocate on women’s rights. THEMATIC AREA 3: RESEARCHING, PRODUCING AND SHARING FEMINIST KNOWLEDGE AND STRATEGIES: Continue to be a reliable resource that offers knowledge and expertise on women’s human rights, and develop, disseminate, and create space for sharing feminist knowledge and strategies, especially against increasing negative trends, both at national and international levels. It is reported by WWHR that, due to the pandemic, all face-to-face activities & communication had to be cancelled throughout the year, and new ways & channels are established, and the existing ones had to be improved to be able to reach the target groups and raise their voice. During this period, WWHR has managed to realise a remarkable success on the social media and has shown a great effort to increase number of followers to implement effective digital campaigns, to reach more people, to improve new communication strategies and to adapt the new normal. Especially developing an influential communication strategy during the Istanbul Convention campaign led to great results in Thematic Area 3. WWHR reached more than 3 million people by organizing effective social media campaigns, production of brochures videos, visuals & animation films, dissemination of visibility materials.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
